frontmatter.title: LROSE Echo and Wind Retrieval Tutorial

children.value: LROSE: The Lidar Radar Open Software Environment Overview

children.label: LROSE: The Lidar Radar Open Software Environment Overview

children.value: The current LROSE release is called “Colette” (a versatile climbing rose) and encompasses six key toolsets that define a core lidar/radar workflow: Convert, Display, QC, Grid, Echo, and Winds. Colette focuses on high-quality, well-tested, well-maintained and well-documented key applications as ‘building blocks’, allowing users to assemble trusted, reproducible workflows to accomplish more complex scientific tasks.
LROSE is a co-operative project between:

Dept. of Atmospheric Science at Colorado State University (CSU) and the
The Earth Observing Lab at the National Center for Atmospheric Research (

).
LROSE is funded by the National Science Foundation.
Please cite the version of LROSE tools you use for publication. If you are unsure of the version, please cite the latest stable release.
: DeHart, J., Dixon, M., Javornik, B., Bell, M., Cha, T.-Y., DesRosiers, A., & Lee, W.-C. (2024). nsf-lrose/lrose-releases: lrose-colette-20240525 (lrose-colette-20240525). Zenodo.
: DeHart, J., Dixon, M., Javornik, B., Bell, M., Cha, T.-Y., DesRosiers, A., & Lee, W.-C. (2024). nsf-lrose/lrose-releases: lrose-jade-20230814 (lrose-jade-20230814). Zenodo.
: Michael M. Bell. (2022). nsf-lrose/lrose-topaz: lrose-topaz-20220222 (lrose-topaz-20220222). Zenodo.
: Michael M. Bell, Michael Dixon, Wen-Chau Lee, Brenda Javornik, Jennifer DeHart, & Ting-Yu Cha. (2021). nsf-lrose/lrose-elle: lrose-elle stable final release 20210312 (lrose-elle-20210312). Zenodo.
: Michael M. Bell, & Bruno Melli. (2020). nsf-lrose/lrose-cyclone: lrose-cyclone release 20200110 (lrose-cyclone-20200110). Zenodo.
: Michael M. Bell. (2019). nsf-lrose/lrose-blaze: lrose-blaze-20190105 (lrose-blaze-20190105). Zenodo.
- Go over the basics to get up and running quickly with LROSE.

- Go through the basic steps necessary to convert a raw radar file to CfRadial, calculate Kdp and three-dimensional rain rate, and estimate the surface rainfall. The purpose of this tutorial is to confirm that the install process was successful and that some programs are working.
- Similar to the basic elle tutorial with the added tasks of downloading GFS analysis from which to estimate a sounding near the radar and running the RadxBeamBlock application.
- This tutorial assumes the user has radar data downloaded in an
and walks through the most important parameters that need to be edited to run the Quantitative Precipitation Estimation (QPE) workflow.
- Convert raw NEXRAD data to the cfradial format and then interpolate to a cartesian grid and applies a convective stratiform separation algorithm.
- run VORTRAC to retrieve the winds using the GBVTD/GVTD algorithm from a single Doppler radar data.
- Step through the processing of a raw radar file through editing, QC and gridding using LROSE and CSU-Radartools
- Go through the steps of applying navigation correction on airborne radar data. Airborne radar navigation correction package can be found
LROSE Echo and Wind Retrieval Tutorial
